Authors:
Alejandra Giraldo, Josepa Gene, Josep Cano, G. Sybren De
Hoog, Cony Decock, Josep Guarro
Title:
Acremonium with catenate elongate conidia: phylogeny of
Acremonium fusidioides and related species
Abstract:
Acremonium is one of the largest and complex genera of
hyphomycetes. Its taxonomy is not yet resolved and the phylogenetic
value of the most distinctive morphological features is unknown. The
species of this genus produce conidia in chains or forming slimy heads
or both. We have studied a set of clinical and environments strains of
Acremonium fusidioides and related species, morphologically
characterized by producing mostly catenate fusiform conidia. Based on
phenotypic data and in the analysis of the sequences of the ITS region,
the D1/D2 domains of the 28S rRNA gene and a fragment of the tubulin
gene three new species belonging to the family Bionectriaceae of the
Hypocreales, are described, i.e., Acremonium pilosum, Acremonium parvum
and Acremonium citrinum. The first species produces two kinds of
conidia, clavate with smooth wall and globose with abundant filiform
projections. Acremonium parvum is characterized by a very slow growth
and pyriform or slightly lanceolate conidia with an elongate and
truncate base. Acremonium citrinum produces a diffusible yellow pigment
and obovoid conidia.
